verses.text: Better a dry crust with peace than a house full of feasting with strife.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes that peace and harmony at home outweigh material abundance. The parallel in Prov. 15:17 makes clear the importance of love over prosperity.

verses.text: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son and will share an inheritance among the brothers.
verses.comment: This highlights virtue and faithfulness as higher than mere birthright. Compare how Joseph, though sold as a slave, was exalted over his brothers (Gen. 41:40).

verses.text: A crucible for silver, and a furnace for gold, but the Lord tests hearts.
verses.comment: Just as metals are purified by fire, the Lord examines our inner motives. Ps. 66:10 and Jer. 17:10 echo this divine searching. Christ later reveals the need for inner purity (Matt. 5:8).

verses.text: An evildoer listens to wicked lips; a liar pays attention to a harmful tongue.
verses.comment: This shows the cycle of sin: those who do evil gravitate towards evil speech. Jas. 3:6 warns about the destructive power of the tongue. Spiritually, avoiding evil company also preserves the soul.

verses.text: Whoever mocks the poor insults his Maker; he who rejoices at disaster will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: Showing contempt for the poor directly offends God, for all are made in His image. This foreshadows Christ's teaching about serving 'the least of these' (Matt. 25:40).

verses.text: Children’s children are a crown to the elderly, and the glory of children is their fathers.
verses.comment: Family blessing is mutual honor across generations. This reflects the commandment to honor parents and the value of faithful lineage.

verses.text: Excellent speech is not fitting for a fool, much less lying lips for a ruler.
verses.comment: Integrity is especially required of leaders. The proverb warns against inappropriate speech and falsehood, especially among those in authority.

verses.text: A bribe is like a magic stone in the eyes of its giver; wherever he turns, he prospers.
verses.comment: This is descriptive, not prescriptive: bribes seem powerful to manipulators, but later Proverbs warn strongly against them (see Prov. 17:23; Ex. 23:8).

verses.text: Whoever covers an offense seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates close friends.
verses.comment: Forgiving and overlooking faults fosters love and communion, which echoes NT teaching on charity covering a multitude of sins (1 Pet. 4:8). Spiritually, we see sins covered in Christ (Ps. 32:1).

verses.text: A reproof impacts a man of understanding more than a hundred blows to a fool.
verses.comment: The wise are humble and receptive to correction, contrasting with the stubbornness of fools.

verses.text: An evil man seeks only rebellion, and a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
verses.comment: Persistent rebellion invites divine justice. Compare with how God sends consequences for sin—see Cain's punishment (Gen. 4:7).

verses.text: Let a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, rather than a fool in his folly.
verses.comment: The danger posed by a fool is even worse than an enraged bear, underscoring the threat of foolishness to community and salvation.

verses.text: If anyone returns evil for good, evil will not depart from his house.
verses.comment: Repaying good with evil brings lasting judgment. This foreshadows Christ's command to love even enemies (Matt. 5:44).

verses.text: The beginning of strife is like opening a floodgate; so abandon the quarrel before it breaks out.
verses.comment: Quarrels escalate quickly—wisdom lies in peacemaking. In the spiritual sense, avoiding conflict preserves unity, which is crucial for the body of believers.

verses.text: He who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous—both are detestable to the Lord.
verses.comment: God requires just judgment. Declaring the guilty innocent or the innocent guilty is condemned. This principle is foundational to Christ's mission to justify the righteous by faith and works (Jas. 2:24).

verses.text: Of what use is money in the hand of a fool if he has no desire for wisdom?
verses.comment: Material wealth cannot buy true wisdom. Desire for wisdom is required to benefit from any gift given by God.

verses.text: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
verses.comment: True friendship is constant and reliable, like the unconditional love of Christ. Brotherhood is designed to see us through hardships.

verses.text: One who lacks sense shakes hands in pledge and puts up security for his neighbor.
verses.comment: Careless guarantees reflect poor judgment. In the spiritual life, one should not take on obligations rashly.

verses.text: Whoever loves transgression loves strife; he who builds a high gate seeks destruction.
verses.comment: Desiring conflict and prideful self-isolation leads to ruin—compare the warning against pride bringing destruction (Prov. 16:18).

verses.text: A perverse heart finds no good, and the one with a deceitful tongue falls into trouble.
verses.comment: The heart and tongue are linked; both must be reformed in the quest for righteousness, which points to the transformation Christ brings (Matt. 12:34).

verses.text: Whoever fathers a fool brings sorrow; and the father of a fool has no joy.
verses.comment: Parenting a foolish child is a great sorrow, reinforcing the importance of raising children in wisdom and faith.

verses.text: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit dries up the bones.
verses.comment: Joy strengthens and restores, but despair harms even the body. Spiritual joy is rooted in the hope given by the Lord.

verses.text: A wicked person takes a bribe in secret to pervert the paths of justice.
verses.comment: Bribery corrupts justice—this is repeatedly condemned in Scripture. Justice must be impartial for true righteousness.

verses.text: Wisdom is in the presence of the discerning, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: The wise see the truth before them, while fools chase after illusions. This encourages attentiveness to God’s guidance here and now.

verses.text: A foolish son is a grief to his father and bitterness to her who bore him.
verses.comment: The pain of parental disappointment is a strong incentive for sharing sound doctrine and wisdom with one's children.

verses.text: It is not good to punish the righteous, nor to strike the noble for their integrity.
verses.comment: This points to the injustice inflicted on the innocent, anticipating Christ’s suffering for the righteous (1 Pet. 3:18).

verses.text: He who restrains his words has knowledge; a calm spirit is a man of understanding.
verses.comment: Wisdom is seen in listening and speaking carefully. Scripture encourages slow speech and a peaceful heart, which fosters Christian unity.

verses.text: Even a fool who keeps silent is considered wise; when he closes his lips, he is thought to have understanding.
verses.comment: Silence is often mistaken for wisdom, teaching humility in speech. This virtue is valued throughout both Testaments for building up the body in love.
